newsitem.title: UK: Brent spreads soften with outright levels, APIs.
newsitem.headline: Brent spreads soften with outright levels, APIs.

text.p: Trade on physical North Sea crude markets was stumped by the fall in outright levels following bearish U.S. stock figures from the American Petroleum Institute, traders said.
Only paper and CFD action was seen over the morning and, as often happens in a falling market, trade was light.
Intermonth spreads on Brent lost ground sharply with June/July trading earlier at +10 cents and offered recently at +8 cents with the best bid three cents lower.
June Brent on the IPE futures market lost 34 cents to trade at 1148 GMT at $19.28 a barrel.
API statistics released late on Tuesday showed a staggering 6.9 million barrel rise in U.S. crude stocks with gasoline up 6.5 million barrels.
CFD's also fell sharply with next week's 19-23 dates at July -14/-10 cents and May 27-30 at July -16/-13 cents.
Oseberg production in June will be hit sharply by scheduled field maintenance.
Traders were somewhat surprised at the June programme which showed the equivalent of 30.7 standard 500,000 barrel cargoes next month against 44.2 in May.
Despite this lighter than expected programme traders said weak fundamentals should drag North Sea crude differentials down in the coming weeks.
A light first decade June Forties and/or Brent programme would help hold differentials in the short term, they added. Those two programmes were expected to be released early on Thursday.
In the Mediterranean Urals demand was healthy with the grade assessed in the dated Brent -$1.10/-$1.00 a barrel range.
Traders grew more concerned over Iraqi Kirkuk exports following the recent rise in crude prices.
One trader familiar with Kirkuk crude said "at these prices there would be difficulties (in loading the full scheduled May volumes)."
Although there were no reports of cargo cancellations or volume reduction as yet, traders said they would not be surprised if volumes were reduced on late May loadings.
Currently the last cargo in May is due to load on May 24-25. No further cargoes would be loading until June 8 at the earliest, traders said.

"It's like taking 400,000 barrels per day out of the market," one trader said, adding that although it was expected it did mean the downside on Urals differentials would be limited over the coming weeks.
